content:
I‚Äôve played Pok√©mon Go on and off since launch, and honestly? At this point it deserves one star ‚Äî and that‚Äôs generous. Nearly every major complaint the community has raised over the last few years is still unresolved or has gotten worse.

1. Remote Raids Were Gutted
The remote raid nerfs were one of the biggest blows to the game. Costs went up, limits were added, and accessibility tanked. Players who can‚Äôt travel, rural communities, and anyone with a busy schedule all got punished. It felt like Niantic forgot the entire reason those raids existed: to let people actually play.

2. The ‚ÄúExploration‚Äù Philosophy Hurts More Than It Helps
Niantic keeps forcing the ‚Äúget outside and walk‚Äù angle by making features inconvenient unless you‚Äôre in a major city. The problem is: not everyone lives in a downtown full of Pok√©Stops. Rural players still get barely any spawns, few gyms, and almost no new stops approved. The ‚Äúexploration‚Äù lecture gets old when the in-game world barely exists outside urban hubs.

3. Event Fatigue & Low Quality Events
Events used to be exciting. Now they‚Äôre constant, repetitive, and full of recycled spawns, bad shiny rates, and FOMO. So many ‚Äúpaid‚Äù events deliver almost nothing of value. You finish one underwhelming event and immediately another one starts ‚Äî usually requiring more money, more passes, and more walking for the same stale rewards.

4. Bugs‚Ä¶ Bugs Everywhere
This game still crashes, freezes during raids, fails to register throws, loses GPS for no reason, and has lag spikes during literally every important moment. For a billion-dollar franchise, the technical quality shouldn‚Äôt feel like a beta test.

5. Too Much Monetization, Too Little Improvement
The shop is overflowing with overpriced boxes and paywalled features, but basic quality-of-life updates (increased storage, better sort/filter tools, better gym mechanics) are slow or nonexistent. It feels like Niantic is always ready to charge for something but rarely ready to fix anything.

6. Communication Is Terrible
Changes get rolled out without warning, player feedback is ignored, and when the community pushes back, the response is usually vague PR language. It gives the impression that Niantic doesn‚Äôt actually play its own game.

content:
Overall, I‚Äôd like to say that this game is fantastic. However, there are a few flaws and such that don‚Äôt make it perfect. For example, sometimes the lack of things to do can lead to boredom. For new players, here is something to note; this game is not good to resort to when your stuck at home. It is an outdoor game and is best played when outside. Continue my review for more in-depth information and thoughts.

There should be some things added to Pokemon Go that would improve it. One of the things I would like the most is the addition of more things to do with your buddy Pokemon. For those who don‚Äôt know, your buddy Pokemon is a Pokemon that you choose to accompany you on your journey. Though you are able to pet, feed and take pictures with your buddy, it‚Äôs all kind of plain. Maybe instead of just petting your buddy to fill up the play hearts, you could actually play with your buddy! There could be toys to unlock, such as rubber bones, tennis balls, etc. With this addition, you could also increase that maximum play hearts from one to three. Another suggestion for the buddy Pokemon is to spruce up feeding them. You simply throw a berry of your choice at them and they eat. What if you could prepare the berries? If you prepared them well, it could make them travel longer with you! This next idea may have a couple flaws, but I also think the addition of beds and dens would be cool. Your buddy could sit in them and relax, though I don‚Äôt know if it would have much of a purpose. Moving away from buddy Pokemon, there are a few more things I would like to discuss. During COVID-19, there was a weekly box for 1 pokecoin. Though I see why the developers wouldn‚Äôt want to add it back due to such a low price, adding something similar would be great. For example, you could sell a few random rare items each week for 50 pokecoins. Though this could leave a dent in currency, it would benefit many players and more people would enjoy the game. I have one last suggestion I would like to make; camera mode. If you click on a Pokemon in the map, you can go into AR mode. But what if you could just look around with the camera and you could find hiding Pokemon? I can see this being fairly complicated, but it would be a game-changing addition and 5-star ratings would fly to the sky. 

There are multiple flaws throughout the game. But I have come up with some ideas to handle them. For one; raids. In quieter towns, you are likely to be the only person raiding, which can be a problem if your trying to take down an opponent with more than 8,000 CP. Considering that the most wanted opponents range between 40,000 - 50,000, this can be fairly hard for some people. To fix this, people in the area should get a notification that a person has joined a certain raid and that they are searching for members. It would look something like this:

‚Äú(Player) is looking for members to help defeat (Pokemon) at (Location)!‚Äù

I know that Niantic Campfire exists for this reason, but it would be easier if you could just get a notification. Another one of the flaws is actually Campfire itself. I understand that it‚Äôs easy for the developers since it supports all their games. But what about the player? Having the download another app makes no sense. Campfire should just be installed into their games. The app can also be dangerous. Announcing your location to anybody with the app is a huge issue. Imagine how many people that just downloaded the app to get someone‚Äôs location? 

But overall, if you‚Äôre thinking about getting this game, I say you should download it. It‚Äôll give you a fun experience if you like to be active and you‚Äôll definitely enjoy it. Just remember to safe and be aware that while this game is good it has its flaws!
